titleStmt.title: The last great and terrible sea-fight between the English and Dutch, on Tuesday and Wednesday last, upon the Western sound neer Cornwal, continuing for the space of two and twenty houres: the particulars of the bloudy conflict; the manner of engagement; and how Sir G. Ayscue charged quite through the enemies fleet with the Rainbow, with the loss of 12 men, and 60 shot in the hull, the number of ships sunk, taken, and burnt on both sides; the great loss that befel the English in the Bonaventure, Elizabeth, and George; the ships rent and batter'd; and Capt. Pack, and divers others, torn limb from limb with canon-shot. Brought by the last post, Sunday August 22. And published according to order.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 7 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

seriesStmt.title: Early English books online text creation partnership.

titleStmt.title: The last great and terrible sea-fight between the English and Dutch, on Tuesday and Wednesday last, upon the Western sound neer Cornwal, continuing for the space of two and twenty houres: the particulars of the bloudy conflict; the manner of engagement; and how Sir G. Ayscue charged quite through the enemies fleet with the Rainbow, with the loss of 12 men, and 60 shot in the hull, the number of ships sunk, taken, and burnt on both sides; the great loss that befel the English in the Bonaventure, Elizabeth, and George; the ships rent and batter'd; and Capt. Pack, and divers others, torn limb from limb with canon-shot. Brought by the last post, Sunday August 22. And published according to order.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for G. Horton; and sold at the Royal Exchange in Cornhil,

notesStmt.note: Signed and dated at end: J. Holding. Plymouth 18 August, 1652.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2013-09 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images

div.p: The la≈øt great and terrible SEA-FIGHT BETWEEN The Engli≈øh and the Dutch, on Tue≈øday and Wedne≈øday la≈øt, upon the We≈øtern Sound neer Cornwal, continuing for the ≈øpace of two and twenty houres: The particulars of this bloudy Conflict; the manner of Engagement; and how Sir G. Ay≈øcue charged quite through the enemies fleet with the Rainbow, with the lo≈øs of 12 men, and 60 ≈øhot in the Hull; the number of ≈øhips ≈øunk, taken, and burnt on both ≈øides; the great lo≈øs that befel the Engli≈øh in the Bonaventure, Elizabeth, and George; the ≈øhips rent and batter'd; and Capt. Pack, and divers others, torn limb from limb with Canon-≈øhot. Brought by the la≈øt Po≈øt, Sunday Augu≈øt 22. And publi≈øhed according to Order.

figure.figDesc: depiction of a sea-battle with two ships or galleons and two smaller vessels

div.p: London, Printed for G. Horton; and ≈øold at the Royal Exchange in Cornhil.

div.head: A Terrible and Bloudy Sea-fight between the Engli≈øh and the Dutch, upon the Coa≈øt of Cornwal: with the particulars thereof; and the number of ≈øhips ≈øunk, burnt and taken on both ≈øides; the like di≈øpute hath not been heard of the≈øe many yeares.
div.p:
ON the fourteenth in≈øtant, the Dutch Armado (con≈øi≈øting of four≈øcore and ten ≈øayl, and twelve Fire-≈øhips) mounted on their Warlike Throne, ≈øet forth Precepts to our ≈øons of Thunder, and cha≈øed Captain Bane into this Harbour, who brings adverti≈øements to the Major and Governour, that the whole Fleet are ≈øtanding
up towards the I≈øle of Wight; from whence we hear, that they bare up on the back-≈øide, and ≈øailed directly to Sir George Ay≈øcue, who were riding thirty miles off from Plymouth: And on the ≈øixteenth in≈øtant, De-Witte their Admiral, with the re≈øt of his Men of War, even like a Grove of Cedars, bore up with hoi≈øted and booming ≈øailes towards the South-Ea≈øt Sound, re≈øolving to act the Theatre of War upon that part of Neptune's Region; in order thereunto, the Vice-Admiral of Zealand, with twenty ≈øtout ≈øhips, and eleven Frigats, drew forth, and prepared them≈øelves for an A≈ø≈øault; which Sir George Ay≈øcue perceiving, gave immediate Orders and In≈øtructions to all his Captains, to ply windward, and to receive their ≈øalutation, which was acted with ≈øuch a revengeful rage, that both parties being inflamed, re≈øolv'd to fight untill the one was tamed; in≈øomuch, that Sir George with the Rainbow, charged them quite through, but not being able to go to the windward of all, received 40 broad ≈øides, and with great difficulty got off, onely with the lo≈øs of three men, and his Bolt-≈øplit. In the mid≈øt of this di≈øpute, the re≈øt of our ≈øhips were not ≈øilent; but each man acted with an irre≈øi≈øtable courage and re≈øolution; And from four of the clock, till 8 at night, the fight was extream hot; Then Nights
≈øable Curtains being drawn the di≈øpute cea≈øed, and both fleets lay in a defen≈øive po≈øture again≈øt each other, with all their lights hanging forth. This Conflict was maintained with great gallantry and re≈øolution on both ≈øides; and great was the execution; for we have received great lo≈øs, the George and Bonaventure, being much ≈øhatter'd and torn, and for the pre≈øent unfit for ≈øervice; divers were rent limb from limb by the Canon-≈øhot; ≈øome had their arms ≈øhot off; others, their legs; among≈øt the re≈øt, valiant Captain Pack, (an excellent ≈øtout Sea-man) hath his leg ≈øhot off; Captain Li≈øle is wounded in the ≈øhoulder, and ≈øince dead; Capt. Clerk is ≈øaid to be ≈ølain, & divers others. Sir George lo≈øt 12 men, be≈øides ≈øome wounded; and received 60 ≈øhot in her Hull; the Samp≈øon, Elizabeth, and divers others, received great lo≈øs, and many a ≈øtout Sea-man hath made the Sea his grave; and too too many (for the pre≈øent) lies langui≈øhing of their wounds.

Yet notwith≈øtanding, the Hollander hath little cau≈øe to brag, for his lo≈øs is exceeding great, many of their ≈øhips are rent and torn; the Rear Admiral is ≈øunk, the Captain of Flu≈øhing, the Armes of Holland (beware the Body next) and three other gallant ≈øhips.

However, the Dutch-men re≈øolved not to decline engagement; but lay in a defen≈øive po≈øture till Tue≈øday morning; at which time, they hung forth their bloudy flag of defiance, on the Top-ma≈øt head; and gave ≈øundry Vollies from aboard, retaining them as Trophies of Victory; the which, did ≈øo exa≈øperate the ≈øpirits of the Engli≈øh, that a Councel of War was called, to con≈øult what to do, in further proceedings again≈øt the enemy, and it was unanimou≈øly re≈øolved by the ≈øaid Councel to ingage them again: Hereupon preparation was made, and after prayers, and ≈øeeking of God, for a ble≈ø≈øing upon their enterpri≈øe, the Admiral, with 33 Men of War, hoi≈øted ≈øail, and ≈øtood up towards them; and about one of the clock in the Afternoon, both Navies engaged, and for the ≈øpace of ≈øeven houres furiou≈øly was the fight maintained, and great execution again
done on both ≈øides, e≈øpecially to the Hollanders; but the night drawing on, the di≈øpute ended: And this morning the enemy had given us the ≈ølip about ≈øix leagues; ≈øome of our ≈øhips are in pur≈øuit; others are, come into this Harbour, with wounded men.

The five hundred men ≈øent from this Town to Sir George, deported them≈øelves with ≈øingular dexterity and courage, and were in the thicke≈øt of the Conflict; many of them are ≈ølain, and about 60 wounded.

This hath been the bloudie≈øt Conflict that ever hapned between the two Republiques; and con≈øequently, 'tis but a begining of the Chaos of confu≈øion; for it is now too late to di≈øpute the Ground-work, the Arguments of bloud being drawn at large in undeniable Maximes: Yet I doubt not, but the Lord will perfect that Work which he
hath thus triumphantly carried on, even for tho≈øe who de≈øire to prai≈øe and magnifie his glorious Name. As for the particulars of the fight, I cannot repre≈øent no otherwi≈øe, at pre≈øent, but that we have taken ≈øeventeen, ≈øunk five, fired two, and di≈øper≈øed the re≈øt; but not without great lo≈øs, as is before ≈øpecified; which is all at pre≈øent, from
